source.raw_text:
Scap Push-Ups primarily target the Serratus Anterior (protraction) and Rhomboids (retraction) for shoulder blade stability, alongside the Traps, Pecs, and Core, using a movement pattern of scapular protraction (pushing shoulder blades apart) and retraction (squeezing them together) in a plank, focusing on shoulder movement without bending elbows to build shoulder health and posture. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers: 

    • Serratus Anterior: Key for pushing shoulder blades away from the spine (protraction). 
    • Rhomboids (Major & Minor): Squeeze shoulder blades together (retraction). 

• Stabilizers & Synergists: 

    • Trapezius (Upper, Middle, Lower): Assists in elevation, depression, and stabilization. 
    • Pectoralis Minor: Helps with protraction. 
    • Levator Scapulae: Connects shoulder blade to neck, aids elevation. 
    • Core (Abs, Obliques): Keeps the body in a rigid plank. [1, 2, 3, 5]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Starting Position: High plank with hands under shoulders, elbows straight, body in a straight line. 
2. Protraction (Pushing Away): Push your upper body away from the floor by spreading your shoulder blades apart, rounding your upper back slightly; keep elbows locked. 
3. Retraction (Squeezing In): Allow your chest to sink towards the floor as you squeeze your shoulder blades together, bringing your body lower. 
4. Repetition: Smoothly transition between protraction and retraction, moving only the shoulder blades, not bending elbows or sagging the back. [1, 3, 6, 7]  

**Citations:**

[1] https://www.instagram.com/reel/DRO9gzsADBA/
[2] https://nielasher.com/blogs/strength-and-conditioning/the-scapula-push-up
[3] https://www.masterclass.com/articles/scapular-push-ups-guide
[4] https://www.instagram.com/reel/DAWeEcgvg0y/
[5] https://backmusclesolutions.com/blogs/the-ql-blawg/scapular-push-ups
[6] https://blog.overtimeathletes.com/try-scap-push-ups/
[7] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LeMk15TN0No
